results.title: What do you think about getting what you're after
results.creator_credit: Gundrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “What Do You Think”.
This film invites discussion of whether, in business competition, one’s standards of fair play should be lowered. The question revolves around two young women who seek the same job. While one has already applied for the position and is reasonably sure of getting it, she lessens her chances by telling the other that applications are still being accepted. A third woman questions the first’s “softness” and the audience is asked to judge. No. 6 in the series.

results.title: Who's running things?
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “What Do You Think”.
The boys in a high-school gym class are penalized by their leader for breaking the rules. The film asks if, after a leader is elected, those who chose him can justifiably override his authority.

results.title: Having your say
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “What Do You Think”.
Are there circumstances in which one group may justifiably deny to another a chance to have its say at a public meeting when a question concerning both is at issue? This problem comes to the fore in a clash between a teenage group and a community center committee. The young people are accused of destructive behavior and are, without a hearing, denied the use of the center. In retaliation they hire a hall to publicly voice their protest. The committee feels it too should be heard at the meeting. The question is left to the film audience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The House on the waterfall
results.brief_description: Acclaimed by the American institute of Architects as the best American building built in the last 125 years, Fallingwater, built by Frank Lloyd Wright has attracted since its construction in 1936 ongoing international accolades. The home built as a summer residence for a family was designed in direct response to it’s environment. The building is sited over a waterfall using mostly counter-levered platforms. The documentary extrapolates on the building method (with archival footage) and details with interviews the materials used and intellectual ideals that directed the external and interior functionalist aesthetics. The documentary observes the home throughout the seasons to illustrate the depth of the Lloyd Wright’s design and his consideration for a place to be lived in and shared with a changing environment. Narrated by Bingo O’Malley.

results.title: The House of cards
results.creator_credit: Paul Seed, Ken Riddington and BBC
results.brief_description: Based on the best-selling novel by Michael Dobbs, a former aide to Margaret Thatcher, “House of cards” is a chilling political expose about the corruption of power, and the unbridled evilness of those who are determined to obtain it at all costs. Ian Richardson gives a brilliant performance as Francis Urquhart, Chief Whip and passed over by the PM in the Party allocation of “Jobs for the boys”. The PM discovers that Francis is a deadly enemy. Enlisting the aid of eager, but novice journalist Mattie Storin (Susannah Harker), Francis uses his undoubted charisma to double deal and murder his way to the top.

results.title: The House of names
results.brief_description: John Smith is convinced that changing his name will change his life. After trying out hundreds of name combinations he sets off for the registry office. But choosing a new name is only the beginning. His journey takes him to the heart of bureaucracy, and what he finds is not only a new identity but a common soul. Cast includes Kym Gyngell, Samuel Johnson, Tom Stringer, Maureen Sherlock.

results.title: The Majority vote
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “What Do You Think”.
A film designed to provoke discussion on the question of whether the elected representative of a group may legitimately support a measure which is disliked by the majority of electors. A situation is presented in which a class of high-school students voice their disapproval of the support given by their student council representative to a measure curtailing their extracurricular activities. In defending her action the representative gives adequate reasons for her support of the measure. The audience is invited to express its opinions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: One man's opinion
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “What Do You Think”.
First in a series of discussion-provoking subjects, this film shows how one person’s judgment might reasonably run counter to the majority opinion. This is illustrated in a high-school classroom where a campaign is under way to raise funds for a school project. One student, although he believes in the cause, withholds his support because he disapproves of the high-pressure methods which put individuals on the spot if they are unable to or do not wish to contribute. The audience is asked for their appraisal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Mountains of memories : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Four stories from people with a deep connection to the Victorian Alpine Country. From different backgrounds, they share their experiences of working, living and travelling to the Alpine country, the stories of ancestors who have mined and lived in the region and how the Alpine country has left an indeliable impression on their lives.
